newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Thirteen burned to death in Malaysia bus fire.
newsitem.headline: Thirteen burned to death in Malaysia bus fire.

text.p: Thirteen Singaporeans burned to death and 12 were injured on Tuesday when their tour bus rammed into a truck parked on the side of a highway near the Malaysian capital.
A police spokesman told reporters all the passengers were Singapore nationals on their way to the Genting Highlands, a hilltop casino resort that is popular with residents in neighbouring Singapore.
Those killed were five men, four women, and four children, police spokesman Mokhtar Hassan told reporters.
Both vehicles caught fire immediately after the bus slammed into the truck, which was carrying scrap metal, Mokhtar said.

Malaysia's Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim promised a thorough investigation into the crash, which occurred at 4.30 a.m. local time (2030 GMT Monday) outside the town of Nilai on the North-South Highway.
The national Bernama news agency quoted the bus driver, who escaped unscathed with his co-driver, as saying that he could not see the lorry he ploughed into.
"I did not see the lorry in the dark and there was no warning light," Rosni Jaat, 31, told Bernama after he was detained by police.
Bernama said most of the survivors crawled out through broken windows. Some smashed windows to escape the burning bus, it said.
Sam Wei Jie, 10, was among those injured.
"My father carried me out and put me on the side of the road but I can't remember what happened after that. There were flames all over the bus," he said.
The boy's mother, aunt and grandfather are believed to be among the dead, hospital officials said. His father and grandmother were admitted to hospital.
Singaporean Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong expressed shock at the accident, which Bernama said was one of the worst in Malaysia's history.
"I am deeply shocked and saddened to learn of the death of so many Singaporeans this morning in the tragic accident on the North-South Highway in Malaysia," Goh said in a statement.
